journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: Hysteresis compensation and high-performance tracking control of piezoelectric actuators

contrib-group.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, Taiwan

author-notes.corresp: Chi-Ying Lin, Department of Mechanical Engineering, National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, 43 Keelung Road, Section 4, Taipei 10672, Taiwan. Email: chiying@mail.ntust.edu.tw

abstract.p: This paper presents a repetitive control-based independent design method for high-performance tracking control of piezoelectric actuators. This work applies an inverse Prandtl–Ishlinskii hysteresis model as a non-linear feedforward compensator to compensate for the hysteresis effect, and validates its inverse model by open-loop compensation. To achieve precision tracking control, the current study designs and implements the feedback control using a prototype repetitive control algorithm, integrating the inverse linear plant model-based feedforward compensation and hysteresis compensation methods to further reduce tracking error. Experimental results and performance analysis demonstrate that using the control structure further improves tracking performance.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Hysteresis has been recognized as a major non-linear phenomenon that significantly deteriorates the tracking control performance of piezoelectric actuators. To compensate for this undesired effect and achieve precise tracking control, significant research devoted to hysteresis modeling and compensation has been conducted over the past few decades.1–7

The current literature related to tracking control of piezoelectric actuators can be categorized into two main groups: independent and integrated design, depending on whether hysteresis dynamics are considered in the feedback control loop. The former is a design, which applies various hysteresis-modeling results as a feedforward input combined with an existing feedback controller for tracking control.8–12 For example, Ge and Jouaneh8 used a regular proportional–integral–derivative (PID) feedback control scheme with a classic Preisach hysteresis model in the feedforward loop for tracking control of a piezoelectric ceramic actuator. In addition to reducing the remaining non-linearities, the feedback action is inevitably included to maintain robustness and disturbance rejection. Adding a feedforward input does not affect the stability of the whole control system; therefore, the designer first designs a feedback control as a performance baseline to satisfy stability, and then obtains improved tracking control performance using an extra hysteresis feedforward compensator. Because of its simplicity and easy implementation, this control structure is popular and particularly suitable for practical applications involving piezoelectric materials, such as nanopositioning stages.11,12 However, one concern of this approach is its limited versatility and performance improvement for various reference input profiles. If the input used for hysteresis modeling and compensator design is replaced with other inputs, an iterative design process may be required to guarantee tracking performance.

The other group, referred to as integrated designs, is a relatively recent and advanced approach, which includes a hysteresis model in the feedback design process as an integrated controller.13–17 Examples include a Smith predictor-based robust H∞ controller using an approximate hysteresis model,13 an adaptive wavelet neural network control with LuGre model-based hysteresis estimation,14 a sliding model controller with modified Prandtl–Ishlinskii hysteresis estimation,15 a neural network adaptive control incorporating the Duhem model,16 and a sliding mode enhanced adaptive control17 based on the hysteresis model reviewed in Goldfarb and Celanovic2 and Adriaens et al.3 In either case, it is expected that stability is highly dependent on the accuracy of the estimates of the parameters in the applied hysteresis model in the feedback loop. This is why these robust and adaptive control techniques have been widely applied to ensure effectiveness, particularly in successful implementation. However, due to the trade-off between robustness and performance,18,19 tracking control performance may be simultaneously sacrificed if the control goal is aiming for high-performance motion control.

To further improve tracking speed and economic benefit from emerging needs in industries, repetitive control (RC) has been reported to be an effective control method, particularly for repetitive motion control of piezoelectric actuated systems.20–23 RC is a feedback control algorithm that includes an internal model of input signals and can effectively reject periodic errors following the internal model principle.24 Rasmussen et al.20 first applied a prototype RC algorithm to a piezoelectric tool servo system for variable depth of cut machining.25 Then, Choi et al.21 and Anh22 included inverse hysteresis models in the feedback for plant linearization with repetitive controllers plugged into the existing PID/PI position control systems. Subsequently, Kim et al.23 developed a hydraulic/piezoelectric dual-stage actuator system for non-circular machining based on a two-parameter robust RC algorithm. More recently, Krishnamoorthy et al.26 and Lin and Tsao27 added a linear plant inversion-based feedforward compensator28 to existing RC systems to alleviate significant transient errors from the learning cycles. However, the dominant hysteresis non-linearity compensated by these linear model-based techniques still exhibits limited performance improvement and needs further investigation.

This research combines an inverse Prandtl–Ishlinskii hysteresis model for a feedforward compensator design6 with a prototype repetitive controller25 aimed at precise tracking control of piezoelectric actuators, recognized as an independent design method. Unlike the RC-based integrated design examples21,22,29 this independent design provides another degree of freedom for performance enhancement19 and an approach to achieve high-performance motion control of piezoelectric actuators that does not suffer from the robustness trade-off problem. As a design guideline focusing on performance, the work also compares tracking control performance using linear and non-linear-based feedforward compensators with feedback controllers, including the traditional PID controller and the repetitive controller.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows: the next section introduces the experimental apparatus and the control structure applied in this study. This is followed by sections that discuss: the inverse hysteresis model-based feedforward compensator design; the feedback controller design for tracking control; and experimental results on tracking control and discussions. Finally, conclusions are drawn.

sec.title: Control structure and apparatus setup
sec.p: As shown in Figure 1, the so-called “independent design” control structure used in the following experiments consists of a feedback controller and a feedforward compensator. This control structure is applied for two reasons. First, the design of these two controllers is independent, showing an “add-on” property for designer convenience. Second, adding feedforward action as part of the control input does not affect the stability of the whole control system. For feedback control, this work applied a PID controller and a repetitive controller for performance comparison in tracking periodic reference profiles. For feedforward compensation, adding a linear plant inversion and an inverse hysteresis (H−1) model compensator further improved tracking performance.

caption.p: Independent design control architecture using feedback controller with feedforward compensator.

sec.p: Figure 2 is a schematic diagram of the experimental apparatus. The apparatus consists of a piezoelectric stack actuator (PiezomechanikPst150/5/20 VS10) and a strain gauge driven by voltage power amplifiers. The maximum stroke of the piezoelectric actuator is 20 µm. The control scheme was implemented using MATLAB®, and the data was acquired by a 16-bit data acquisition card (NI PCI-6052E) at a 10 kHz sampling rate. The measured output datum under regulation with no reference commands has a sensor noise level of 7.9 nm. This study applied this apparatus to implement hysteresis modeling and controllers for tracking experiments.

caption.p: Schematic diagram of the experimental setup.

sec.title: An inverse hysteresis model-based feedforward compensator design
Hysteresis modeling using the Prandtl–Ishlinskii hysteresis operator
sec.p: Studies have typically applied the Prandtl–Ishlinskii model to reduce hysteresis behavior in piezoelectric materials.6 Applying this model results in two main advantages. First, using backlash operators can simplify the complex mathematical model. Second, the inverse model can be calculated analytically. The following introduces the procedure for building a Prandtl–Ishlinskii model and its inverse model for hysteresis compensation.
The elementary operator in the Prandtl–Ishlinskii model is a backlash operator, shown in Figure 3, which is defined as

where H denotes the backlash operator, x is the backlash input, l(t) is the output response of the operator, p is the input threshold value or the magnitude of the backlash operator, ws is the weighting value, l0 is the initial state and T is the sampling period of the operator. The initial condition of this operator is given as

caption.p: The backlash operator in the Prandtl–Ishlinskii model.

sec.p: Figures 3 and 4 represent the relationship obtained by varying the parameters p and ws in the backlash operator. Figure 3 illustrates that the width of the hysteresis loop increases and the peak-to-peak output of the backlash operator decreases with an increasing threshold p. Figure 4 shows that the weight value only influences the amplitude of the output.

caption.p: Hysteresis modeling using the Prandtl–Ishlinskii model by piezo output : different number of applied operators.

sec.p: A Prandtl–Ishlinskii model utilizes these characteristics to model non-linear hysteresis by superposition of several backlash operators with different threshold and weighting values. The mathematical equation of the model is

Hysteresis modeling is based on the curve showing the input and output relationship. Considering the same given input, this work compares the piezoelectric actuator output with the Prandtl–Ishlinskii model output for modeling purposes.

One approach to evaluate model accuracy is to use dynamic motion profiles as an input, such as transverse scanning motion in precision measurement applications, and then compare the desired position with the actuator’s output. This study applies a special triangular curve for modeling and validation because this input, moving back and forth with varying magnitudes, can easily excite the non-linear effect originating from backlash operators in the applied hysteresis model. A special characteristic of the Prandtl–Ishlinskii model is that the model only needs three operators to approximately describe the hysteresis curve, as shown in Figure 4. Although using more operators leads to a greater model accuracy, the overuse of operators influences real-time control efficiency and complicates the parameter tuning process. This study built a hysteresis model using 15 and 9 operators, with similar modeling accuracy. This result demonstrates that the Prandtl–Ishlinskii model only needs a few operators to obtain acceptable modeling results.

In Figure 5, nine operators are applied to model the hysteresis curve excited by the trianglular wave decreasing from 12 µm. The piezoelectric actuator’s output response only achieves about half of the desired displacement, demonstrating that the non-linear hysteresis effect strongly influences the piezoelectric actuator. Next, applying these hysteresis curves the hysteresis model was built by curve fitting. The modeling results indicate that the Prandtl–Ishlinskii model output is similar to the piezoelectric actuator output as shown in Figure 5. The results indicate that the Prandtl–Ishlinskii model successfully describes the hysteresis curve in the applied piezoelectric actuator. The obtained parameters are directly used to model the inverse hysteresis model in the next section.

caption.p: Hysteresis modeling using the Prandtl–Ishlinskii model by piezo output: triangle wave (attenuated from 12 µm).

sec.title: Implementation of the inverse Prandtl–Ishlinskii model
sec.p: To compensate for the hysteresis effect, researchers commonly apply the inverse hysteresis model as a feedforward compensator. The most important advantage of the Prandtl–Ishlinskii model is that its inverse model is still a type of Prandtl–Ishlinskii model but with different threshold and weight values. The number of inverse operators is equal to the number of operators used to model the hysteresis curve. Therefore, the parameters of the inverse model can be found by6
The inverse of the Prandtl–Ishlinskii model is a reflection along a 45° straight line, and the parameters of the inverse model are obtained as6

The inverse Prandtl–Ishlinskii operator given by the transformation laws does not change the structure of the Prandtl–Ishlinskii hysteresis operator. This convenient formulation makes the model easy to implement and suitable for real-time control applications.

sec.title: Hysteresis model validation
sec.p: To clarify how this inverse hysteresis model helps to compensate the hysteresis effect, the built model is placed just before the plant (piezoelectric actuator system) to validate the built hysteresis model by open-loop compensation. Figure 6 and Table 1 show the compensation structure and identified parameter values in equation (4).

caption.p: Parameters for the identified inverse hysteresis model.

sec.p: The first trajectory for model validation is a ± 4 µm displacement and 1 Hz sine wave. Figure 7 shows that the open-loop compensation result and the piezoelectric actuator output with compensation (red line) almost achieve the desired position (blue line). The maximum tracking error is constrained between −0.1 and 0.2 µm. The result demonstrates that the inverse model can effectively compensate the hysteresis effect.

caption.p: Hysteresis model validation: 1 Hz sine wave.

sec.p: Next, the trajectory frequency was increased to 10 Hz and the same compensation structure was used to validate the built inverse model. Figure 8 demonstrates that the maximum tracking error increases by approximately 50%. This result represents a decreased compensation performance using the model built for a 1 Hz sine wave. Although the error increases, it only loses 6% tracking accuracy of the desired trajectory. The solution to this problem is to build the hysteresis model with the desired trajectory.

caption.p: Hysteresis model validation: 10 Hz sine wave.

sec.p: To validate the effectiveness of the built hysteresis model, a multiple frequency trajectory was used as the desired input trajectory. The trajectory consisted of 1–5 Hz sine waves with a maximum ± 12 µm displacement which can be expressed as

Figure 9 shows the experimental results. The hysteresis effect is significantly more evident when the desired displacement is increased. The maximum compensation error is between 1 and −1.2 µm (approximately 11%). However, the applied hysteresis model still compensates for the hysteresis effect. Figure 10 illustrates the input–output response plots of the piezoelectric actuator with (red line) and without (blue line) compensation in the experiments. The blue lines show that the downward path does not follow the original upward path. This fact indicates that the hysteresis effect greatly influences the transverse position of the piezoelectric actuator. Therefore, this study applies the inverse Prandtl–Ishlinskii model to compensate for the hysteresis effect.

caption.p: Hysteresis model validation: multiple frequency sine wave.
Open-loop hysteresis compensation results: (a) 1 Hz sine wave; (b) 10 Hz sine wave; and (c) multiple frequency sine wave.

sec.p: The discussed validation experiments for the hysteresis model impart some significant information. First, the hysteresis model design should be based on reference profiles to achieve the best performance. Second, the performance of tracking complex trajectories is not guaranteed. Applying more operators may improve tracking performance, but the computational burden also increases. Performing complicated modeling is impractical because open-loop compensation results highly depend on modeling errors. To obtain superior robustness and handle disturbance rejection, the use of feedback control is inevitable. Feedback control is effective in tracking control if appropriately designed. The following introduces the feedback controller design methods applied in this study.

sec.title: Feedback controller design
sec.p: To achieve precision tracking control, this study applies the general PID controller and a repetitive controller. The following introduces the design methods of these controllers.

sec.title: General PID controller
sec.p: To highlight the necessity of using a repetitive controller, this section introduces the PID controller for trajectory tracking. The PID controller is a commonly applied controller that uses proportional, integral and derivative actions on the control error to regulate controller output. Equation (10) shows the transfer function of the discrete time PID controller
where Kp is the proportional gain, Ki is the integral gain, Kd is the derivative gain and Ts is the sampling time.

The selection of PID parameters is intuitively straightforward. Proportional control is used to increase the transient speed of the output response. Integral control is used to eliminate steady state error and derivative control is used to reduce overshoot. The PID controller can quickly obtain effective results, especially for step tracking. However, its limited performance for dynamic motion profiles has resulted in the creation of the model-based repetitive controller design method discussed in the next section.25

sec.title: Repetitive controller
sec.p: To improve the tracking performance of piezoelectric actuators, RC control is applied to track the periodic signal at desired frequencies. This paper utilizes the repetitive controller design method discussed by Tomizuka et al.25 and its block diagram is shown in Figure 11. As a feedback control design method, a repetitive controller contains the internal model of input signals (i.e. periodic signal generator) as part of the controller and asymptotically tracks reference signals following the internal model principle.24
The repetitive controller Crep includes an internal model represented as25

where N is the number of the period signal, and L is the sum of the plant delay and the controller delay from inverting the unstable zero part in the closed-loop plant. CZPETC, a stable inversion of the plant dynamics, is the zero phase error-tracking controller (ZPETC), is designed using the method reviewed in Tomizuka28

where A(z−1) includes all poles of the plant, Bu(z−1) includes all unstable zeros of the plant, Ba(z−1) includes all stable zeros of the plant, and Bu(1) scales the steady state gain of the controller. kr is an adjustable learning gain with a value typically ranging from zero to two.25 Apart from kr, the ZPETC feedforward compensator design is the same as the controller in equation (12).

Since the repetitive controller design always includes high-gain feedback at high frequencies, which may excite unmodeled dynamics and induce instability during implementation, a zero phase low-pass q-filter is added which can suppress this undesired effect. The q-filter is selected as

where a and b satisfy 2a + b = 1 for unity DC gain, and n is a positive integer. Although q(z, z−1) is a non-causal filter, the controller’s causality is still ensured because of the cascaded long delay terms z−N and z−N+L.
To ensure robust stability of the repetitive controller design, the following inequality that relates the plant model uncertainty Δ to q has to be satisfied30
where G is the actual plant, and Ĝ is the identified plant model, meaning that |G–Ĝ| represents the modeling error.

Other than robust stability, another approach to evaluate the tracking performance of the repetitive controller is to check the transfer function from the reference r to the tracking error e, also referred to as the sensitivity function S31
where Crep is the repetitive controller introduced in equation (11). Substituting equation (11) into equation (15) leads to the following more detailed representation

sec.title: System modeling and identification
sec.p: The following tracking control experiments require an accurate model of the piezoelectric actuator for the ZPETC compensator and repetitive controller design. In this work the piezoelectric actuator is represented using the second-order equation32

where U and Vo represent the maximum stroke and voltage, respectively. F is the force factor, cm represents elasticity, mm is the effective mass and rm is energy loss. For practicing engineers, this equation provides a guideline for power amplifiers and related electronics design, and is particularly useful for further controller design and analysis. However, the equation only contains the piezoelectric stack dynamics without considering the dynamics of the applied power amplifier and sensor amplifier. Therefore, to obtain a more practical model for the following model-based controller design, this study applies a system identification method, which considers the system from piezo-power amplifier input to sensor amplifier output to obtain the overall piezoelectric actuator system model.

sec.title: Tracking control results
sec.p: This study obtained a frequency response plot and its curve fitting using an Agilent35670A dynamic signal analyzer. The results are shown in Figure 12, and the system bandwidth (–3 dB) is approximately 670 Hz. The current study obtained a second-order system model using a frequency domain system ID approach33 which was used to design the repetitive controller and ZPETC compensator.

caption.p: Piezoelectric actuator frequency response and curve fitting.

sec.p: In a first set of experiments results were obtained using a PID controller integrated with different feedforward compensators. The PID gains were tuned for the piezoelectric actuator tracking control (Kp = 3, Ki = 7500 and Kd = 0.0001). The experiments applied an a ± 4 µm displacement and 10 Hz sine wave as the desired trajectory.

The experimental results shown in Figure 13 show that a steady state is reached in 0.1 s. Feedback control obtained a superior tracking performance as compared with that for open-loop compensation as shown in Figure 8. Although using a more accurate hysteresis model increases open-loop tracking performance, the burden of using more operators and parameter tuning with specific tracking profiles, as well as disturbance rejection issues, means that feedback control is preferred for use in common piezo-tracking control applications. However, tracking error using the PID controller does not converge to a minimum, and the steady state still has non-convergent oscillations. Integrating feedforward compensators can ease this problem as shown in the plots.

caption.p: The 10 Hz tracking error experimental result: PID versus PID+(ZPETC)FF versus PID+(H−1)FF.

sec.p: Comparing the tracking errors obtained using the ZEPTC and H−1 compensators, the H−1 compensator obtained the better tracking performance. The maximum tracking error obtained using the ZPETC compensator was ± 0.035 µm whereas that for the H−1 compensator was ± 0.02 µm.

These results obtained using the PID controller display significant oscillatory behavior at steady state. This effect will limit its application in precision engineering applications. Due to its observed ability to track periodic signals and reject periodic disturbances,25 the current study utilized the repetitive controller as the feedback controller for trajectory tracking in the following experiments.

To guarantee that the designed repetitive controller satisfies robust stability and meets the expected tracking performance, a controller analysis procedure was performed before it was used in experiments.

Figure 14 shows that the designed repetitive controller should satisfy the robust stability condition in equation (15). A higher cutoff frequency of the q-filter indicates a less robust repetitive controller.

caption.p: Robust stability analysis of the designed repetitive controller.

sec.p: For performance analysis, the sensitivity function is plotted following the equation introduced in the section “Repetitive controller.”Figure 15 shows that deep troughs occur at multiple frequencies of 10 Hz. This result shows that the designed repetitive controller based on the 10 Hz fundamental frequency can obtain an optimal control performance. As the cutoff frequency of the q-filter increases, the trough depth also increases, thus contributing to a superior control performance. Increasing the cutoff frequency of the q-filter can lead to the robust stability condition being violated. This study chose a q-filter of 0.25z+0.5+0.25z−1 for the repetitive controller design.

caption.p: Sensitivity plot of the designed repetitive controller.

sec.p: Then, the designed repetitive controller was integrated with the feedforward ZPETC and H−1 compensators for trajectory tracking. The learning gain in the repetitive controller was taken to be 0.4 in the following experiments. The desired trajectory was an a ± 4 µm displacement and a 10 Hz sine wave. The observed experimental results are extremely different from the ones using the PID controller as shown in Figure 16.

caption.p: The 10 Hz tracking error experimental result: RC versus RC+(ZPETC)FF versus RC+(H−1)FF.

sec.p: The results show that the RC requires a convergence time of approximately 2 s to reach steady state operation due to the long-term delay utilized in the repetitive controller. The basic idea is to generate an internal model of the desired trajectory as part of the feedback controller to achieve superior tracking performance at steady state operation.25

Figure 16 shows that integrating the ZPETC compensator reduces the convergence time to approximately 0.5 s and minimizes the maximum error at the transient state to approximately 50% (between ± 2 µm). In Figure 16, the convergence speed when using the H−1 compensator doubles, compared to only using the repetitive controller. The maximum error further reduces between -0.5 and 1.2 µm.

From the performed tracking control experimental results, it is clear that feedforward compensators increase convergence speed and reduce transient state tracking error. The experimental results demonstrate that a non-linear compensator is a better choice than a linear compensator for compensating the hysteresis effect.

To demonstrate the performance of the repetitive controller in motion control, the trajectory frequency was increased to 100 Hz and a controller was designed based on a 100 Hz fundamental frequency. The tracking error shown in Figure 17 shows that the performance of RC + H−1 is superior to PID + H−1 after 0.05 s, achieving steady state operation after 0.08 s. The tracking error of PID + H−1 is 50 times larger than for RC + H−1 at a steady state conditions. The convergence speed increased significantly in tracking a significantly faster (100 Hz) profile. The experimental results indicate that the repetitive controller with feedforward hysteresis compensation is able to obtain a good performance in tracking periodic signals.

caption.p: The 100 Hz tracking error experimental result: RC versus. PID+(H−1)FF versus RC+(H−1)FF.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This study applied the inverse Prandtl–Ishlinskii model and RC to improve tracking performance of piezoelectric actuators. The experimental results offer certain conclusions. First, obtaining a good hysteresis model involves a few Prandtl–Ishlinskii operators that effectively increase performance by compensating for hysteresis in the piezoelectric actuator. Second, the repetitive controller achieves good high-frequency tracking control of piezoelectric actuators. Finally, using the repetitive controller integrated with the feedforward compensator provides fast convergence speed and very good tracking control.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research was funded by the National Science Council of Taiwan under grant NSC 97-2218-E-011-015.
